newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Arabs, Jews apprehensive in Hebron.
newsitem.headline: Arabs, Jews apprehensive in Hebron.

text.p: Palestinians and Jewish settlers in Hebron, long arch-antagonists, voiced opposition on Tuesday to a pending peace deal which would in effect partition the West Bank town between PLO and Israeli forces.
"What kind of peace have they brought us? A city divided like East and West Berlin? Now we'll have North and South Hebron," Palestinian Hebronite Majdi al-Fakhouri told Reuters.

As Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Yasser Arafat held a summit on the Israel-Gaza border on Tuesday to clinch a long-elusive deal to hand over 80 percent of Hebron to PLO self-rule, Arabs and Jews braced for a new reality in the volatile town.

"We're crossing our fingers that this agreement which God forbid will bring catastrophe on the oldest (Jewish) community in the world in Hebron won't be signed," settler Moshe Ben Zimra told Israel Radio. "This terrible agreement will endanger our security."
Israeli troops were due to withdraw last March from most of Hebron -- holy to Moslems and Jews and a hotbed of militancy for both -- under a 1995 peace deal.

But then-Israeli leader Shimon Peres delayed the pullback after a wave of Islamist suicide attacks killed scores in Israel 10 months ago. The handover was pushed off further when the hardline Netanyahu ousted Nobel laureate Peres in May.
Netanyahu has demanded the Hebron deal be modified to help protect Hebron's 400 Jewish settlers who live and study in heavily armed compounds amidst more than 100,000 Palestinians.
The Palestinian Authority has resolutely opposed any changes in the signed deal.
Israeli troops will continue to control 20 percent of Hebron -- and some 15,000 Palestinians -- after the redeployment.
"What will be changed for me? I'll still live under Israeli occupation and settlers will have more harassment against me," coffeeshop owner Abdel Raouf al-Muhtaseb complained.
Hebron was mostly quiet on Tuesday as Arab and Jew awaited news from the U.S.-brokered talks. But the volatile city has been rumbling in recent days.
At least two Palestinians were taken to hospital on Saturday when Arabs and Israeli troops clashed after Jewish settlers scuffled with Palestinian school children in the town.
Israel imposed a curfew on central Hebron on Sunday after a number of molotov cocktails were thrown at Jewish homes there. The curfew was lifted Tuesday morning, the army said.
The city has seen much worse.

In February 1994, U.S.-born Baruch Goldstein from nearby Kiryat Arba settlement massacred 29 Palestinians kneeling in prayer at the burial place of the biblical Abraham before survivors beat him to death.
Jewish settlers fear the introduction of armed Palestinian police in Hebron will lead to a repeat of the 1929 slaughter of the city's Jewish community.
Hagai Ben-Artzi, a Hebron settler and brother-in-law of Netanyahu, held out hopes a "miracle" from God would stay the Israeli leader's hand from signing an accord.
"The people of Israel has already lived for 4,000 years on miracles. It could very well be this miracle will occur," he told Israel radio.
